question: Outline the type of monomers required to form a polyester via condensation polymerisation.

sample_answer.full_answer: A diol and a dicarboxylic acid (or derivatives) react to form ester linkages (2 marks).
common_mistakes: Stating only one monomer or referencing alkenes (addition polymerisation).

question: Explain why removal of water during condensation polymerisation increases polymer yield.

sample_answer.full_answer: Condensation polymerisation is reversible; removing water shifts equilibrium toward polymer formation (Le Châtelier's principle) (2 marks). Higher conversion leads to higher molecular weight (1 mark).

marking_criteria.criteria: References equilibrium shift when by-product removed.
Links conversion to polymer molecular weight.

common_mistakes: Saying removal of water slows the reaction.

question: A polyester is formed from ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid. Calculate the theoretical mass of polymer produced from 0.500 mol of each monomer, assuming complete conversion and negligible end groups.

sample_answer.full_answer: Repeat unit (C10H8O4) has molar mass 192.1 g mol^-1 (2 marks). 0.500 mol of each monomer produces 0.500 mol repeat units (1 mark). Mass = 0.500 × 192.1 = 96.1 g (1 mark).

marking_criteria.criteria: Determines repeat unit formula/molar mass correctly.
Identifies limiting stoichiometry (1:1) giving 0.500 mol units.

common_mistakes: Adding monomer masses without subtracting water.

question: Compare addition and condensation polymerisation in terms of monomer functionality and by-products.

sample_answer.full_answer: Addition polymers use unsaturated monomers (typically alkenes) and produce no by-products (2 marks). Condensation polymers use multifunctional monomers (diols, diacids, diamines) and release small molecules like water or methanol (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: Describes addition polymer requirement and absence of by-products.
Describes condensation polymer monomers and elimination of by-products.

common_mistakes: Confusing addition polymerisation with step-growth mechanisms.

question: Design a laboratory investigation to model condensation polymerisation using readily available reagents, describe observations, and evaluate safety considerations.

sample_answer.full_answer: Use nylon rope trick: react adipoyl chloride (in hexane) with hexamethylenediamine (in water/NaOH) at interface (2 marks). Observations: polymer film forms at interface and can be pulled as fibre (2 marks). Safety: adipoyl chloride is corrosive and releases HCl; use gloves, goggles, fume hood, and dispose solutions properly (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: Describes setup and reagents for interfacial polymerisation.
Discusses safety measures (corrosive reagents, HCl release, PPE).

common_mistakes: Ignoring safety issues associated with acid chlorides.
